fields.description:
With the new unified console, users should be able to download their credentials once logged in (after approval by Admin). We should provide a little button or dropdown option to provide this functionality. 

Summit planning: this ticket is scoped assuming we are implementing only the ability for users to create and download a new set of access/secret keys from the account menu, which would then be made active automatically. It *DOES NOT* include managing their other keys, deactivating or deleting. 

There are two options for implementing conditional display on the menu option (so that it only dispays for users that can access this function):
     1) console would need to test that the user has access to iam:createAccessKey. If they do then console can create and download key. Console can use this API call to test whether to conditionally display the option, but if we do, we would be downloading new keys every time the user logs in, and we would have to clean those up, so it's a lot of overhead. 
    2) If the back end (CLC side of the world) implements dry run (it is not currently in boto for IAM and is not in amazon IAM docs, but it is implemented in EC2 and would be useful in this case), then the console could test whether to conditionally display this menu option without creating keys. AWS EC2 implements dry run, but AWS IAM does not. Note that IAM features are not supported in the euca management console at all, so this would be OK as a euca extension. Needs architectural review. [~decker]

T SHIRT SIZE SMALL
fields.summary: Allow users to download credentials from unified management console

comments.body: [~lwade] WS is deprecating this functionality for access keys *and* passwords, they are both only downloadable now at the time of creation only. We're doing the same thing, however, we are allowing the admin to email the user their creds and PW at time of creation so they will have them there. I hope that helps.
Sorry, what is "WS"? Oh, so a user cannot go and retrieve the access keys or change their password via the new console? I think this might need to be revisited based on feedback we've had.

Sorry, AWS is what I meant. More coffee please. 

Users can change their password, and we could add something to request new keys too, I think. I will look into that.
Oh gotcha.  Ok, yes please consider this as this functionality is quite valuable to existing customers and users.

In the *vast* majority of cases I've seen its just to get their API keys.  They may have mislaid them or need them on a different machine.  For the most part they don't need the other bits, so maybe instead of something "physical" we just show them, which would be more secure I'd imagine.

[~lwade] [~rusvika] [~shashi] this functionality is in the admin console and so is not really available to regular users now. Is this something we would want to allow for *any* user, or just for those that have permissions to access the IAM functionality? In the current 4.0 designs this functionality is included only for account admins (i.e. those that have permissions set to access IAM functions), where they select a user and download the access keys or password. Please see https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Single+User+View for 4.0 wireframe for this

Should this instead be accessible by the user? We could put this under the account menu for any logged in user. Please let me know if that is what you are requesting, and should this functionality also be available to the admin? Would a policy need to be in place granting permissions to the user to access this functionality?

cc: [~kgill] [~dkavanagh]
[~jloza], in AWS, any user can create/change various credentials if this user has appropriate IAM permissions. The same holds for Eucalyptus through CLI.

[~rusvika@eucalyptus.com] we have the change password option under the account menu for that reason, so that this one function is accessible if perms allow it, even if they don't have the perms to describe IAM users. That is why I was thinking the download credenttials option could also go there. [~shashi], [~lwade], do you think that the download access/secret keys option should be available under the username@account menu where change password is located?
^ this sounds good to me.

This does sound pretty simple. We give every user the menu option. That will generate a new access/secret which they will download as a .csv. If they lack permissions, we'll generate an error message instead. [~jloza] in this case, we might want to provide a custom message instead of a permissions message from the CLC. Could you provide text?

[~jloza], that's OK if the keys are made active automatically by default, but we should be careful about letting users to generate an unlimited (or large) number of active keys (AWS wisely limits the number of keys to 2, we currently don't but that's a bad practice). Users should either be very clear that each download results in a new pair of active keys or to have an option not to activate the keys (which probably does not make a lot of sense for key download).
Thanks, [~rusvika]...we'll try and make the messaging super clear about active keys, and recommend letting their admin know so that they can consider deleting unused or obsolete keys.

If a user has permissions to create a new access key, I'd think that he/she is likely to have permissions to manage (delete/rotate/etc) these keys. We should consider enabling key management for regular users (if their permissions allow that) as a part of this feature request.
[~rusvika] I'd love to keep the scope of this small to try and get it implemented ASAP. We can always look at full key management as a follow on if you don't mind.

[~dkavanagh], wireframe available at https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Create+access+keys

and for nav: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Header%2C+Footer%2C+Nav

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/887

Check this out and pass to Kamal for code review, pls.

Dialog and menu item look good, but when I went to the user page for this user (admin@uitestacct00) the new key was not listed. 

See attached screenshot.
I'm seeing a problem where none of the keys for that account are listed, yet landing page shows 7. Will debug that.
ok, GTG now.

[~jloza]: Requiring the "Create access keys" link on the username drop-down forces us to add that code to the master template (which is loaded on every page).  Could we link to a page from the "Create access keys" menu item instead of opening a modal?  That would allow us to pull in the create access key code only on that page instead of pulling it in on every page, which I'm hoping we can avoid, especially since the create access key operation will be used relatively infrequently.

/cc [~dkavanagh]
I thought about putting the js code into a file, so that it would be cached and no longer part of the template. I think that would help a lot.
[~kgill], [~dkavanagh], a page seems really heavy-handed for just a message and button. Maybe David's option would work, putting the .js code into a file?
moved javascript into file. Comments in commit.

Support for policy variables (EUCA-8582) would simplify permitting credential management for non-admin users . Support would allow creation of a policy permitting users to manage their own credentials ( http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/Credentials-Permissions-examples.html#creds-policies-credentials ) so a policy per-user would not be required.

added show keys option to manage credentials wireframe per discussion in arch mtg 9/5/2014.

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Manage+Credentials

passing to Jenny for UX, then should go to Kamal for code

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/913

Passed UX review, except for the help icon needs some love, the ? is not centered in the circle. Can you please fix that as part of your code review, just to move this to QA faster? I feel like it's something to do with the fact that it's needing to be aligned with a subsection-label instead of just a label, but IDK how to fix it myself or I would have.
I saw the tests passed, so I merged it.

[~dkavanagh], [~jloza]: The only way I was able to allow a user to generate their own access key was to allow them full IAM rights.  I tried to add custom policies that included all AccessKey rights and also tried the policy as described here:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/Credentials-Permissions-examples.html#creds-policies-credentials.

None of that worked.  Please tell me if I am missing something.  This doesn't sound like the expected behavior.
I don't have that answer. Maybe [~sjones] can help because he knows the back-end permissions checks better.
We do not currently support policy variables (EUCA-8582) so you would either have to create an IAM policy specific to each user or allow users to access each others credentials.

[~ccassler], that works as expected for me:

{code}
# euare-accountcreate -a sjones
sjones	299584785139
#
#
# euare-usercreate --as-account sjones -u sjones
#
#
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account sjones -u sjones -p iam -o '{
>   "Version": "2012-10-17", 
>   "Statement": [
>     {
>       "Action": "iam:CreateAccessKey", 
>       "Resource": "*", 
>       "Effect": "Allow"
>     }, 
>     {
>       "Action": "iam:DeleteAccessKey", 
>       "Resource": "*", 
>       "Effect": "Allow"
>     }, 
>     {
>       "Action": "iam:ListAccessKeys", 
>       "Resource": "*", 
>       "Effect": "Allow"
>     }, 
>     {
>       "Action": "iam:UpdateAccessKey", 
>       "Resource": "*", 
>       "Effect": "Allow"
>     }
>   ]
> }'
#
#
# euare-useraddkey --as-account sjones -u sjones
AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ
WZP....
#
#
# euare-useraddkey -I AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -S WZP.... 
AKITVSFFSPY8CWVUHS66
bW7MBEn0rlKFG5nmY4Hcmvt4h10T2HMxLomRQvG3
#
#
# euare-userdelkey -I AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -S WZP.... -u sjones -k AKITVSFFSPY8CWVUHS66
#
#
# euare-userlistkeys -I AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -S WZP.... 
AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ
Active
#
#
# euare-usermodkey -I AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -S WZP.... -u sjones -k AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -s Inactive
#

# euare-userlistkeys -I AKILIT3FTPJIEHRRI2XZ -S WZP.... 
euare-userlistkeys: error (403 Forbidden): Invalid access key or token
#
#
{code}

so creating a user with the policy you supplied and then performing access key actions as that user.

I tried generating keys using the above policy in addition to a policy that grants access to ec2 and sts commands. The request fails becasue the server side tries to issue iam:GetUser. At this point, we can insist that privilege be granted, or I can re-code the request handler to simply use the name provided in the URL, which would be fine as well.


https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1229
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1229
PR 1229 merged
